Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2011 10:46PM - edited Feb 6, 2011 10:59PM by americanpinay Hi Kathleen, I love and trust my onc and would probably agree to whatever he recommends for my follow up care. Having said that, I sometimes think that he is on the aggresive side of things. My insurance is probably NOT loving him. Based on what I have read on this board, some oncs do not recommend anything, not even blood tests, unless there are symptoms. I also read somewhere that intensive follow up care do not improve survival and that early detection does not apply to mets. I, for the life of me, cannot get my head around that. I somehow think that finding mets early would and should help. Don't cancer cells go amok (for lack of a better term) when left untreated? One thing is for sure, I will continue to have an internal debate about whether these tests are worth it. BTW, my rad onc is on the less agressive side of things. He was very respectful of the other onc's opinion but did wonder out loud why a PET scan was recommended after treatment. I wish you luck in your appointment and I hope that you'd be able to trust the type of follow up care that you decide on.  Take care. Lumpectomy 09/08, AC x 4 then Taxol x 12 10/08 through 03/09, Rads x 33 05/09 through 06/09 Tamoxifen beg 08/09 Diagnosis: 9/10/2008, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIIa, Grade 2, 4/6 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2-
Posts.Title: Until the next scare... americanpinay americanpinay

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2009 01:21PM americanpinay wrote: My onc did not want to do the PET/CT while I was undergoing active treatment. We also waited three months after rads before doing any scans. My understanding is that chemo or rads could produce false positives. Waiting for test results is hard enough as it is and inconclusive test results just make it so much worse. Good luck with your decision.

Posts.Title: Stage 3 and 4 over treated? RANT LittleC lorieg

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2009 10:19AM americanpinay wrote: Hi. I had 4 A/C every three weeks and then 12  weekly Taxol. TMI Alert!!! One thing to watch out for on A/C is constipation.  I had major constipation after the first treatment. Onco nurse told me to take Colace (stool softener) after my second A/C and all is well.  I had nausea and vomited some after my first A/C but that was because I was hard-headed and did not take my anti-nausea pills as prescribed. You will get through this.  It is doable.  Take care.

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2011 04:24AM americanpinay wrote: Hi Wolfspring, My onc tells me that PET/CT scans can't tell for sure if any area of concern is cancer or not. Only biopsies can tell for sure. I know it's hard but try not to worry too much about the scan. I try to think of tests/scans as things I gotta do to make sure that if there is something to be concerned about that it gets taken care of ASAP. Hang in there. Hope you get great results!

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 04:50PM americanpinay wrote: Hi Jackie, First, congratulations on finishing treatment. About your scan question, it looks like you had a PET before treatment and it showed some activity on your lymph nodes, is that correct? Then I would do another PET because I would want to know that treatment took care of those areas of concern. Just keep in mind that tests beget tests. I should know as I had a whole bunch of scans recently. What I had learned from this experience is that scan results can't really give me the peace of mind I'd like to have. Going forward, I have to think of tests or scans as things I have to do to make sure that, if there is something going on, it could be taken care of ASAP. Good luck with your decision. Take care.

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2009 02:44AM americanpinay wrote: Hi...I haven't had a bone scan but I had a PET/CT scan three weeks ago...you don't eat the night before the test...they inject you with radioactive sugar...supposedly, cancer cells love sugar so that when they scan you, the cancerous areas light up BUT sometimes areas light up because of benign conditions (for example, infection) so the results need to be compared to other tests...hope this helps...good luck to you...

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2011 01:16PM americanpinay wrote: Hi Karina, I did not have neoadjuvant chemo, just adjuvant chemo.  I think adjuvant (after surgery) chemo is recommended 99.9 percent of the time, if not 100 percent, for Stage 3. If I remember correctly, I read that neoadjuvant chemo is not prescribed as often as adjuvant chemo.  I believe neoadjuvant chemo is commonly prescribed for IBC or if the doctor wants to shrink a huge tumor before surgery. I wish you well in your treatment. Chemo really is doable. At the risk of sounding trite, this too shall pass.  Hang in there.
